prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 370 um in zC412369/zC401417
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 370 um continuum, chance for serendipitous detection of CO 7-6/[CI] 2-1 in USB

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We predict the TIR luminosity of our targets from their SFR using the calibration by Kennicutt & Evans (2012, ARAA, 50, 531). The resulting TIR is converted to a flux density at 370 um by assuming graybody emission with an emissivity exponent beta=1.5 and a temperature of 35 K. This temperature is on the high end of what is expected for galaxies with z=2 and the SSFR observed in our galaxies (according to Eq. 5 in Magnelli et al. 2014, A&A 561, 86), yielding a conservative estimate of the 370 um flux. It also is consistent with the results of Yang et al. (2007, ApJ 660, 1198) for temperatures at high redshift (see their Fig. 7). For the same assumptions detailed in the [CII] science goal (assuming 80% of the emission is resolved into 4 beams) we expect S/N~8-4. For a 32 K temperature (as predicted by Magnelli), we expect S/N~10-5.
We have placed the CO 7-6 and [CI] 2-1 transitions in the upper sideband to maximize serendipity. It is difficult to predict the strength of these transitions, since it depends on the excitation condition in the gas, but even for pretty low excitation sources (such as the Milky Way) CO 3-2, 7-6, and [CI] 2-1 have similar fluxes in nW/m2 (Fixsen et al. 1999, ApJ 526, 207). So we expect them to be detectable with our integration time.
These galaxies are grouped in our science goals to minimize calibration overheads, since they have very similar redshifts.

We aim to maximize continuum sensitivity and aim at the possible detection of CO 7-6 and/or [CI] 2-1. The TDM resolution of 40 km/s seems too coarse, so we use heavily averaged FDM 1.875 GHz windows for the possible location of these lines.

See discussion in next science goal ([CII])
We are matching resolution with the [CII] observations. This would correspond to C36-5, which makes it also possible to schedule these observations at night during May.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in zC412369/zC401417 in the LSB
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup places the image sideband (USB) in a more transparent part of the atmosphere. Precision of redshift is 110 km/s (1-sigma; Lilly+ 2009).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In order to compute the expected [CII] intensity we use two methods: 1) the relation between [CII] and SFR, and 2) a photodissociation region model for general conditions Go~1e3, Go/n~1 to predict [CII]/FIR vs. CO/FIR. Both approaches yield very comparable results within the natural uncertainties. We use the Herrera Camus et al. 2015 calibration of [CII] vs. SFR for the KINGFISH sample (i.e., normal galaxies), which is compatible with the ISO results from Bosselli et al (2002) and de Looze et al. (2011). The comparison with the GOALS sample (LIRGs) results indicates that the CII deficit does not significantly affect the calibration for resolved star formation ***surface densities*** of the order of the average surface density in our objects (Herrera Camus et al. 2015), but determining whether the [CII] emission is "normal" or not is one of our science goals. The corresponding equation relating SFR and [CII] luminosity is:
SFR = 2.29e-43*L([CII])^1.034 (Herrera-Camus et al. 2015)
This expectation of relatively bright [CII] emission and normal [CII]/FIR ratios is borne out by a number of recent ALMA and APEX work at high redshift (Riechers et al. 2014, Schaerer et al. 2015, Capak et al 2015, Brisbin et al. 2015), so we think it is very realistic. For the sake of completenes, we also predict luminosities using the calibration of Sargsyan et al. (2012), which corresponds to the LIRG/ULIRG regime and is heavily affected by the [CII] deficit. We adopt a standard cosmology, which results in a luminosity distance of 1.6e4 Mpc and a scale of 8.5 kpc/arcsec for z~2.
For our galaxies, with a typical SFR~100 Mo/yr, we predict a [CII] luminosity of 3.9e9 Lsun, and a flux density of 118 mJy in a linewidth of 200 km/s if the object is unresolved. For the calculations in the OT we assume that 80% of the flux of the object is resolved in 4 beams (of 0.3", or 2.6 kpc), yielding an expected signal of ~30 mJy over 200 km/s. We aim for a sensitivity of 1.3 mJy over the same bandwidth. The resulting S/N is >20 for either observation.
If we were to adopt the Sargsyan et al. (2012) calibration, which we think is pessimistic in this case, we obtain a luminosity 3 times smaller (1.2e9 Lsun), which for the same assumptions will yield S/N~6-7. So we are garanteed to detect [CII]. In fact, if the objects are as luminous as we expect, we will be obtaining 5-sigma detections in 12.5 km/s wide channels (i.e., nicely resolving the kinematics).
In our two z=2.02 targets the spectral setup is designed to cover the maximum bandwidth to increase the chance of continuum detection, although our calculations suggest that we do not expect to detect the rest frame 160 um continuum. By tuning with [CII] in the LSB, the image sideband is placed in a transparent part of the atmosphere.

The correlator configuration has been carefully designed to be able to use it simultaneously for both galaxies thus minimizing overheads, and to place the sideband in a transparent region of the atmosphere (since this is a DSB receiver). We are using TDM with 14 km/s channels, so the data rate is not a problem.

LAS: at 8.5 kpc/arcsec these galaxies are not going to be bigger than 2", in fact, their actively star-forming region is likely much smaller. Bolatto et al. (2015, submitted) for example find 50% diameters of 8 kpc (i.e. ~1") in two z~2 main sequence galaxies for the CO 1-0 emission, which would be closely correlated with the [CII] emission. The galaxies here are smaller in SFR and stellar mass.
Angular resolution: 0.3" (2.6 kpc) in C36-2 allows us to likely measure disk sizes and resolve the kinematics without over-resolving the emission (i.e., still having a good S/N per resolution element). Furthermore, baselines are still short, relaxing the atmospheric stability requirements and minimizing decorrelation. Also, this configuration is scheduled in March and these objects could be observed at night. I necessary for scheduling, the angular resolution requirement could be relaxed to 0.2" to allow observation in C36-3 during April (where high frequency weather may be more easily available).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in zC405501
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Very high precision Ha redshift from SINFONI. This is tuned to place the CII in the LSB and avoid placing basebands in opaque regions of the USB.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The discussion of the S/N estimate is covered in the previous science goal. We relax the noise requirement by 20% here because the target is in a less transparent region of the atmosphere and we want to keep the proposal to a reasonable time. We still expect to observe the target with very good S/N in [CII].
Our lowest metallicity galaxy is at z=2.15, which places the [CII] near the lower edge of the tunable range of the B9 LO. The redshift of the target is very well established, however, and the band covers +/-460 km/s around it, so we do not expect problems missing the emission. This target is in a less transparent part of the atmosphere and requires a longer integration. Unfortunately the presence of atmospheric absorption in the image band impedes doing a good job with the continuum (which is unlikely to be detected in any case).
The configuration is chosen to minimize the noise from the image sideband. See also discussion in the previous science goal.
Covered in the previous science goal, please refer to that text. Apparently I need to add text here to reach 50 characters or the Observing Tool fails to validate it.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 370 um in zC405501
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 370 um continuum, chance for serendipitous detection of CO 7-6/[CI] in USB

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: See previous 370 um goal. The targets have very similar SFRs and consequently similar predicted fluxes per the SFR-to-FIR relation.
See previous 370 goal, the full justification is in there. Once again, the OT wants to see 50 characters. I could copy it here, but it would obscure the fact that there is nothing new.
See previous 370 um goal, the full justification can be found there. Once again, the OT wants to see 50 characters

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 3-2 in zC405501
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Get good S/N measurement of CO 3-2 in our lowest metallicity target Other windows are configured for continuum/serendipitous line detection

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on the PDR models mentioned in the [CII] science goal, we predict a CO 3-2 intensity of 0.75 mJy in a 200 km/s linewidth for this target, which is compatible with the measurement obtained by PHIBSS, and it is also compatible with measurements in similar low metallicity northern hemisphere PHIBSS targets (e.g., Genzel et al. 2012). We thus expect a S/N~5 with an on source integration of 50 minutes. Note that even though we expect to detect this source, even if we do not detect it the result would be important and provide a very strong limit for the "CO-dark" molecular gas and the CO-to-H2 conversion factor in this galaxy.

The primary goal is CO 3-2, with continuum as a secondary goal. Serendipitous discoveries of CO emission in other galaxies in the FOV (companions) have occurred for PHIBSS, so it makes sense to maximize the bandwidth with OK spectral resolution. To reduce the data rate we heavily spectrally smooth the data (x16, which gives 20 km/s resolution, which should be enough).

The goal is an unresolved spectrum of the entire source, matching the same type of data we have for the rest of these sources and the entire PHIBSS+PHIBSS2 sample. Given the configuration schedule it makes sense to request a resolution similar to what would be obtained in C36-2 or C36-3

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The bulk of the star-forming galaxy population forms a tight "main sequence" in stellar mass versus star formation rate. Increasingly, observations of the H2 content of main-sequence galaxies at high-z probe smaller galaxy masses and subsolar metallicities, and already experience the problem of weak CO emission well known in local metal-poor galaxies. We propose to image at 2.5 kpc resolution the [CII] transition and dust continuum on 3 main-sequence galaxies at z~2 that span a metallicity range Z~0.3-1 Zsun and have a host of ancillary information, including Ha imaging, to: 1) obtain resolved kinematics of the neutral gas to test the Violent Disk Instability scenario, 2) probe the "CO-dark" H2 and investigate the CO-to-H2 conversion factor, and 3) study the photoelectric heating efficiency in a regime not explored before. These galaxies are part of the PHIBSS/PHIBSS2 CO and SINFONI samples which provide key molecular gas, resolved Ha, and metallicity information. Our goal is to improve our understanding of the impact of physical parameters on the tracers of ISM in z~2 main sequence galaxies.
